p: Juglone belongs to the naphthoquinones, a group of secondary metabolites with cytotoxic properties that are widespread in Nature. Naphthoquinones are synthesized in more than 200 species of higher plants representing the Droseraceae, Ebenaceae, Juglandaceae, Plumbaginaceae and other families [ 175]. As of today, juglone was extracted from plants of the following species in the walnut family ( Juglandaceae): Persian walnut ( J. regia L.), black walnut ( J. nigra L.), Manchurian walnut ( J. mandshurica Maxim.), pecan ( Carya illinoensis (Wangenh.) K. Koch), Caucasian walnut ( Pterocarya fraxinifolia Lam.), etc. [ 176]. Studies demonstrated that juglone was able to produce inhibitory effects on the insect larval development, sedative effects on fish and animals; besides, it developed antimicrobial, antifungal, and antiparasitic activity [ 177]. In addition, juglone manifested activity against many types of tumors [ 178].
